content: With all due respect, I think you’re missing the point of unsolicited redesigns. They are fun design explorations. No brand requirements, no product design restrictions, no insider information that would shackle ideas. No “this is the way we’ve always done it” debt, just pure exploration. Someone did an unsolicited redesign of my company and our team loved it. (https://dribbble.com/shots/2876030-Stackoverflow-redesign if you’re interested) In fact, my company does an exercise we call 5% fun that has similar rules: throw out all constraints and just design something different. Do we ever ship these designs? Absolutely not. Do we ever ship parts of these designs? You bet. Did we get ideas from the fellow who redesigned our site above? Absolutely. Ideas come from everywhere: analytics, user research, established design patterns… and design explorations like this. If you’re tired of seeing these pop up in your feed, take some time to adjust your feed instead of writing things that put other people down. On the outside chance you’re interested in why I like and actively use other people’s unsolicited redesigns in my own paid product design work, I wrote about it: https://medium.com/@tedgoas/an-open-letter-to-designers-of-unsolicited-redesigns-and-unbuildable-apps-44048ba16b76
